reviewText:
this saint seiya game is a fighting game that if you're a hardcore fighting game pro-player or whatsoever, you might not like it since the figting mechanic isn't that deep.
the game is designed to be easy-to-play, you can do  combos without smashing buttons until they pop. the gameplay is kinda like naruto, if you had played one.

so let's get to the pros/cons real quick

+ soooooo many playable characters.
+ great special effects, so colourful. you go wink wink wuub wuub and boooomm .
+ beautiful bgm, BEAUTIFUL BGM.
+ you can buy costumes, characters, assist phrases (runes),.etc with your in-game currency. it'll take an age if you're 'gotta catch em all' type of player.
+ it's the MOTHERF-ING SAINT SEIYA lads.

+/- not so deep fighting mechanic, like it or not is up all up to you. i like it tho.

- the story is too fast-paced, if you haven't watched the anime, somehow, you might get a little bit lost.
- stages need to be purchased with your in-game money to use in versus mode, you can't just get it when you playthough the story.
- most lines are.... awkward. you know, typicall old anime style.
- the animation when they talk makes it even more.... awkward. they don't even make sad face when they're sad (you can tell that by the voice).
- if you play online and the game matches you with a player from the opposite side of the world, the game will be laggy as hell.

after getting a new character, i'll try out combos on saori
10/10 would pegasus ryuseiken that b*tch again.
...and again

actually it's a 7/10 if you want a serious review

reviewText:
Playing this game was like getting shot back to 1986 when Saint Seiya popped out from the void of an artist's imagination and turned into a popular Japanese anime. Finally, after 29 long years of countless manga, anime/movie adaptions and five game releases, it is good to know that we have yet again been blessed with a sixth addition to the video game series!

Saint Seiya: Soldiers' Souls is based on a very old anime where you take the role of four Saints of Athena; Seiya, Shun, Shiryu and Hyoga -- and sometimes Ikki if he's not too busy being a badass. The Saints' jobs are focused on the constant protection of the world from numerous perils along with safeguarding Athena who, despite being a Goddess of War and Wisdom, tends to get herself endangered quite often. Clad in Cloth -- magical armor blessed from the empyreal constellations above -- the four Saints (and occasionally five) must battle against strong foes and maximize their true potential!

The game, like the show, is a part of the fighting style genre. The game play mechanics has increased and improved drastically since its predecessors. These Gods are equipped with a variety of attacks ranging from basic to heavy attacks along with special moves; it’s easy to execute successful combos, making this a great pick for those who are not skilled veterans to the genre and would like to start somewhere light and easy. The controls for combat are smooth and definitely feel quick; I enjoyed the wide range of different fighting styles each character had to offer along with a player roster of 72, so trying them all out will be a task in itself but won't feel like a chore.

The cinematics and graphics aren't at its optimal level, nor is it chiseled to perfection, making the main campaign feel lackluster every time a character is perceived having a traumatic moment. While playing it, the player will come to think, But is it sad? I don't know
date: his eyes are too damn pretty to look at!" But it’s to be expected
recommended: it’s a fighting game and most fans of the genre don't care much for the emotional rollercoaster
hoursPlayed: which is what visual novels are for! The price of $59.99 is steep but it's understandable for a big name title since most games standard point is $74.99-79.99

reviewText:
I really recoomend it if you are a fan, or at least know the history of the anime and enjoy a fun fighting game

PROS
* original voices - excelent voice acting, well synced
* lots of characters (although they could have inclued some silver saints and more specters)
* fun to play
* gameplay improvement compared to the previous games
* nostalgia
* multiplayer works just fine (I have NOT experienced lag)
* almost all sagas of the anime was covered
* no bugs - yeah, it would be mandatory, but lately all games are released with bugs (some major and big annoying ones) so this is (sadly) becoming a diferential
* MODS! the game looks like really easy to MOD, and some MODs are already on the scene, with new custom models/ sounds
* special moves animation are really similiar to the way saints perform it on the anime series

CONS
* no OST ( can be fixed with a MOD that puts the original musics in the game )
* no intro movie
* no bonus stage
* no animation of any saint dressing the armor, one thing that i really enjoyed watching on the anime
* lame cutscenes - almost no animation, saved by the voice actors that did a great job
* history is resume to a point that if you dont know it already you will be lost
* graphics could be better (worse comparing dbz/naruto games)
* fighting could be better too (comparing what we can get from dbz/naruto games)
* characters not really well balanced - there are some Saints that are a little stronger/easier to use then others (but all games have balance issues and maybe a patch can solve this)

reviewText:
The true worth of this game in my opinion is based on 2 elements:

1. Nostalgia.
Bring back memories of our childhood, watching them on tvs and such. Of course, it is also good for people who never knew about Saint Seiya, there will be new wave of fans.

2. Simplicity
The combat mode is very simple rather than Tekken, Street Fighter, and Dragon Ball Xenoverse. People will easily learn combos and find a character that will match their own fighting style. The rest is for players to formulate their own combos and play style and climb up the ranking system on online mode.

The graphics is also quite good, but it feels like a bit below Naruto and Dragon Ball.

On the other hand, I am quite disagree for the price. It should be around USD 10 lower than the current release price.

reviewText:
TL;DR
With just under 10 hours of playing this game I can safely say that this is not a title for people who are not familiar with the Saint Seiya universe and lore.
The game does not take the time nor apologize for simply narrating the very big overall plot points of the series.

This game is, however, a must have for hardcore Saint Seiya fans who were lamenting the lack of a PC version to play with.
Falling in this category, I am having the best of time rediscovering the main fights from the this beloved series.

Comments
Cons of the game overall:
Character models -- character models are hit and miss. The Shingo Araki style has been emulated but not everywhere and not for everyone: Soari looks terrible, Saga and Canon have terrible hair models, etc...

Visual Narration -- a lot more could have been done to hype a lot of the fights up in the cutscenes.

Background music -- The gorgeous original series score is not in the game. Not licensed for our markets. Thanks fully, there is a mod for this. Makes the games instantly burn its cosmo!
voteText: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is better than its predecessor. It has revamped gameplay and new combo system, allowing final attacks to fit into combos, just what it needed.

I'll go straight to the cons:

- Bad animations in story mode. Yeah. Developers STILL (after... 6 games¿?) don't put effort into this, so you'll see Camus and Hyoga intact without any trace of ice on their bodies after Aurora Execution dialogue or Saga killing himself with the Gemini armor put on. Not to mention Shura's arm. Basic mistakes that weren't even put a single effort in it.
- Frame rate drops like HELL in certain scenarios like Star Hill, making the game unplayable but that could be just me.

Pros:

- Inclusion of the God Warriors was about time.
- Better combos than the previous game.
- Better light effects on the scenarios
- Scenarios beautifully made and their recreation is faithful to the anime.

tl:dr Asgard chapter fans should buy it, the ones that have played Brave Soldiers aren't missing much but the God Warriors.

reviewText:
All original characters, voices, animation & fighting styles. If you are a fan of Saint Seiya, then this game is stronly recommended for you!

Fair warning to those whom' are unfamiliar with the Saint Seiya series, there is no solid story in this game that will go through explanation for the game's story gameplay. If you are interested in the game, I strongly recommend you watch the Saint Seiya series, so you don't sit there wondering what the heck is going on.

Fighting combos/controls are easy to learn and use with almost all characters in the game. If anything, this is just a fun-casual fighting game not a serious one like Dead or Alive. So don't expect anything big in the battle system.

The animation for each characters Burst Attack (Their ultimate move) is lovely.

For its price, I say it is well worth if you are a fan of Saint Seiya or fighting games.

10/10 Would use Rising Dragon" on Saori again. (If you know what I mean). ;)"

reviewText:
After 4 years, this is the first review I write. This 1st Saint Seiya game is good and long, and becomes excellent with the music mod available on the forum, the AI is polished and I still not dare to change the settings to Hard, I´ve played many SS games where the CPU ended with lot of exploits, here you can have surprises.

Lot of game modes, not just the 4 story arcs, a Battle of Golf mode, Galaxian wars, survivals and who knows if there are more surprises, the game doesn´t get all unlocked in 1 day, neither in 2.

As a true fan, I´ll point the most severe flaw: the english subtitles at least have lot of fails/or imprecissions who are going to be caught by the public this game is intended on.

For the love of God, is not Hades Generals, they are the 3 Judges!!!!! There are some other translation fails but are minor.

Anyway great job overall, and of course, if you like the Anime this game is mandatory

reviewText:
I have zero knowledge of the whole Saint Seiya universe. Instead of buying all kinds of manga and anime to get into it I decided I will be getting this game instead. I was hoping that Saint Seiya: Soldier's Soul  would work as an abridged version of the stuff I would otherwise read or watch…

Unfortunately, that is not the case - pretty sure that this game works best if you are already way into the source material. Storymode tosses you right into the action, without any real introduction to anything. To add insult to injury all the cutscenes  are really bland (unlike the Big Bang Attacks during the actual fights ingame) - so I ended up skipping them all after the first couple of stages. After having completed the storymode portion of the game I now know more or less as little/much about Saint Seiya as before.

Apart from that, the game itself is rather boring as well. In the same vein as many of those other Anime-based arena fighters like Naruto or Dragonball Xenoverse. It controls somewhat decent, but a couple of design decisions aren't my cup of tea (like, Special Moves all trigger a cutscene before actually executing the move and you get no i-frames once the game switches back from movie mode" to the actual fight meaning you will more often then not get punished and kicked out of your special before anything noteworthy happens or limiting the arena with invisible walls). It's a kinda hectic
date: buttonmashy affair with no real lasting appeal. The "Super"-Attacks look amazing
recommended: but they are merely cutscenes - the rest of the game consists of evades/dodging and fishing for openings to attack/counter-attack. The dreadful camera (angle) doesn't help. I am pretty sure I would enjoy this more if it was a classic 2D fighter
hoursPlayed: something along the lines of SEGA's / ASW's Fist of the Northstar.\n\nOnce you are done with Storymode
voteText: there are a bunch of other modes to try out - but none of them struck me as particularly interesting. It all boils down to 1 on 1 fights
helpfulPercent: just with different conditions to earn more money or unlocks - but since the fights aren't all that fun to begin with
votesHelpful: this just seems like a huge waste of time. I feel like the main reason for their existence is to have something to grind the ridiculous amounts of money needed to unlock a ton of collectibles - turning this game into another stupid grindfest for the sake of longevity or that replay value-BS. Something that I find REALLY off putting about games these days.\n\nAs stated earlier
votesTotal: might be worth a look if you are into Saint Seiya
votesFunny: but everyone else can skip this entirely. You ain't missing out."

reviewText:
Well the fighters all have pretty unique styles and feel like the original characters, so that's cool.  However, this also seems to make a few of them just completely unstoppable.  I'll admit I've only played the single player, but for instance I have yet to actually take a hit while playing Andromeda.

Speaking of which, the singleplayer is pretty good with quite a bit to do.  The AI plays pretty aggressively from the outset, which is nice compared with other fighting games where you've always got a few rounds of way-too-easy opponents before any difficulty kicks in.  The cutscenes are godawful though.  I mean okay, to be honest Saint Seiya was never great story/character material to begin with; the characters were always painfully cliched manime archetypes, but absolutely zero time has been put into animating the models or faces for cutscenes in this game, so what you get is a character standing in his respective fighting or standing stance, and moving his lips while the rest of his face remains perfectly still.  Come on guys, it's a sixty dollar game, make the faces expressive.  I also would have liked it better if we could change the stories like in some of the Budokai games.  I find myself just skipping all the story stuff, which is something I generally don't like to do.  Story mode also does that thing where it makes you play all the characters instead of just playing through one's story, which I find aggravating.

Anyway, the fights are fun and a lot more interesting than fights in Saint Seiya ever were, and there's a pretty robust single player mode, so that covers the two major areas for my dollar.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Alright, so having finished with this game, I do have a few choice words for it.  For one, this being a game where you'd have to rely more on strategy than just straight going toe to toe, this works in a fighting game.  For the most part, it's a fighting game where you'd have to anticipate attacks constantly whereas in other games is more who combos first.  Since I relied mainly on both for certain characters, it draws a learning curve more of how you should fight than who to fight with.  There are characters who are fast enough to flat out chase their enemies and catch them offguard with either melee or cosmo attacks, characters who strongly rely on cosmo alone then those who have short ranged melee attacks or just slow with melee but cosmo attacks are just that powerful. The Cosmo Attacks are pretty lengthy and can sometimes cost you the battle but again, it comes down to strategy.  This is a thinking man's fighting game so it's not as spam happy as Street Fighter is. So for those who have it and don't like due to lack of speed and whatnot, it's not that kind of game.  For someone like me, it works.  I'd say this: if you like Saint Seiya or you're a devoted fan of the series, get it for that reason alone. The story cuts it down to where it matters and worth playing through.  Try it if you like it, that's all I can say.

reviewText:
As a Saint Seiya's fan I recommend this game if you feel nostalgic about the series. As a fighting game however, there are better games out there. Overall I'd give this game a 6/10, maybe a 7 on a generous day. The fact that most moves are the same on all the characters is a bit of a downer, but it's also nice if you don't have the patience to learn new combos.

Let me clarify: the special moves are all triggered by the same combo. Even though you get different cut scenes and different moves. So you the timings are different and the situations you might use them in are different (somewhat). There are some minor combos that differ, too.

They attempt to tell the anime's story, but they leave a lot out. For a beat-them-up though, the story is as good as it's going to get. No English dubs, but then I have never seen the anime itself dubbed in English, although it was dubbed in my native language back in the 80s. You do get subtitles but the translations leave somewhat to be desired in places.

You do get to play the Sanctuary saga, Asgard, Poseidon and Hades, you unlock a lot of characters with their gold or god cloths. That is bound to wet the apetite for the hardcore fans.

TLDR: If I wasn't a Saint Seiya's fan I wouldn't have bought this. I do enjoy it for what it is, and for the fans I'd say it's worth getting but perhaps when a sale is on.

reviewText:
Saint Seiya: Soldiers' Soul is a anime-based game, the setting is as the following, five Bronze saints were gathered and trained during their childhood, when the time was right, they were fated to protect Athena, namely Saori Kido (the goddess) and fight for the just cause.
She was supposed to be residing in her Sanctuary with her army of saints (the Gold Saints and the Pope) devoted to her, however, instead, the Grand Pope Arles pulls the strings in the shadows and steals the influence she should have had over those said saints by revealing lies to them, such as Athena alread being in the Sanctuary (but not showing herself due to her high status as a Goddess).
They indeed believed him and thus, to make sure he'd keep his reputation clean, he ordered one of his minions to end Athena's life with a golden arrow, and so, the five Bronze saints' quest to rescue Athena begins.

Overview:

Gameplay: 7/10

Saint Seiya: Soldiers' Soul is a fighting game which involves two buttons combinations as a layout, light and heavy attacks, the purpose of the game is pretty simple once you get used to it. Nonetheless, there's a variety of combos and features that will get you hooked onto your gamepad, I found myself hugging the controller because I was pushed to make full use of it. Most buttons, more or less, have a purpose, whether it's to recover, guard, or go on the offensive.
The ultimate" attacks
recommended: are quite satisfying. Being faithful to the anime/manga
hoursPlayed: the scenes are immersive and the effects are magnificent

reviewText:
I remember when I was a kid and I had to struggle to stay awake to watch Saint Seiya and other anime series on TV. I know all their names, constellations, techniques, fighting stances, remarkable phrases... Everything. When I look at the series now they seem a bit silly. But still, I am a die hard fan, and I vowed that I'd never buy another anime game if this one sucked. Thanks be to Athena it did not come to that...

The game follows a very similar style as DBZ Xenoverse (same game engine I suppose), with graphics going heavy on the idea of preserving the anime-feeling in the air and simple fight mechanics with simple button smashing and timing strategy. I could not find any of the original songs from the series, don't know if I still need to unlock them, but what I heard of BGM on the stages pleased me.

But of course, the objective here is not a complex fighting game like KoF, SF or MK... This thing shoots at the series' fans, so I'll tackle the matter from this angle: the game is a jab of nostalgia right in the kisser. Seeing those old friendly (and some not THAT friendly) faces again almost brings a tear to my eyes... But what got me were the voices. I am Brazilian, and voice-acting around here back in the late 80's and early 90's was, at least for me, top-notch... And the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s brought back almost all the voice actors from the original series. I laughed with joy like a child at every technique name they cried. I admit that it is not what it used to be. I don't know if the quality really dropped or it is because I remember the voices differently... But still, it touches me (in a decent way, pervs).

So, if you are a fan of the series, I really recomend it. It is a ticket to the Nostalgia Train.

Para os parceiros BR huehue zueiro por ai: MORRA SEIYA SEU VIADINHO!

EDIT: Why did they censor b a s t a r d s" ? There are worse words out there

Over all that I still recommend it since its Saint Seiya a more mature version of power rangers.

reviewText:
A dyed horse. Another game. Same contents.

Saint Seiya: Soldiers' Soul is another Saint Seiya game which all fans would buy but not all would love. The most impressive thing about the game is that the moves are almost all overhauled, with powerful and satisfyingly explosive light show. All Big Bang Attacks are brilliantly impressive. The new God Clothes added for Gold Saints look all awesome, and the cinematic of their ultimate moves are done so well I can tell that most of the game budget went into doing it. They are so accurate that they will trigger your nostalgia, reminding you how awed you were when you saw those moves for the first time.

Unfortunately, that area is the only area that has seen improvement. The game STILL have the same story as the previous game. Same narrative. Same characters. Same fighting style. The story is the same one as told the previous hundred times. You fight the same characters over and over, using different fighters, in different places. The narrative tosses away almost all the iconic moments of the series. Aurora Execution vs Aurora Execution was done through a conversation. The fighting is pitifully shallow and doesn't take much to master. Characters, while listed as high as 72, at least a third of them are the same characters wearing different costumes. God Clothes, while beautiful beyond words, are just another aesthetic gimmicks, albeit very well done ones. Big Bang Attacks, while powerful looking, are just aesthetic cinematic scenes. Prominent characters with great roles in the series are slopily skipped. Where is Papillon Mu? The fight lasted an entire volume. Where is Worm Raimi? The one that almost killed Aioria. Where is Barog Rune? The one that almost kill Shun and sent Seiya to hell? Where are all the new characters? The production of this game is like dying a horse and selling it. It gets away with adding the least content while presenting it as a new game. Pass this one if you're looking for something new. Stay away.

reviewText:
sloppy graphics, sound sync, controls... This had to be the perfect game, why did they drop the ball on this one? Even Naruto ninja storm has better voice sync and graphics. The good point is that the original voices are used, so it gave me the nostalgic time I used to watch the anime on TV. The story is a quick glance of each arc, which is good and bad (if you are new to Saint Seiya, you will miss many stuff you should know).

The controls are weird, because you can't stop a combo sequence when the enemy avoid your attack, it feels very broken. Also, when you use the cosmo-dash to reach the opponent, most of the time I end up rushing to the opponent, and then, instead of stopping when I reach it, it keeps rushing for about a second, which gives to the enemy a golden chance of storming a sick combo on me.

I don't recommend this game. If it was free, or much more cheap, it would be kinda recommended, but overall, I, sadly, don't recommend this game. And I love Saint Seiya. I feel sad because I had so many expectations on this game, and it is too mediocre.

reviewText:
The story telling in this game is so poor and broken that I cannot recommend it to anyone looking for something other than a quick combat with a friend. Hell, it would've been better if it had no story at all and a much lower price.

They could've used parts of the anime for cutscenes instead of in-game crappy animations. That would've helped a lot in situations where a character talks about some past events. What happens when a character remembers some past events? – you might ask ~ Well, they show the character on a black, empty, background … talking.

The story telling is so bad that I'm almost glad they didn't include Black and Silver saints, or the Soul of Gold chapters. Playing through the story mode was painful. You'll be better off skipping any and all cutscenes.

Graphics aren't too bad. Characters are okay. Backgrounds are mediocre at best. The animations during a Big Bang Attack are good. Probably the only good thing about the game.

Music is awful. There's not much else to say about it. Just. Awful.

Gameplay is very basic and becomes rather boring after a little while.

This is one of those cases where a game developer lands a license for a popular TV series franchise and tries to make a quick buck.

If you're interested in a game with a strong single-player campaign and good story telling then run away and never, I repeat, never look back. If you, on the other hand, just want to kill some time with a friend, then wait for a big discount. The $49.99 USD asking price is way too much for this game. A fair price would've been $19.99 USD.

reviewText: As a fan of Saint Seiya, I can say this is a pretty great game. It brings me back to the GNT 4 days ( a Naruto title) in terms of the combat system, which is a very good thing!  Not super complex, but there is definitely depth to mastering it.  The game really carries the spirit of Saint Seiya, and the music is excellent.  Controls are tight, amazing variety of characters, lots of different playstyles.  Definitely worth the purchase!  Side note: There are a TON of unlockables, which is something you don't see in a lot of titles now and days.  This is welcomed by me, as I grew up in the early 90's where you had to earn new characters, costumes, etc. and not pay for them.  Love it!

reviewText:
This is the first game of the series I play, and as a fan of the anime during my childhood, it was quite a trip back down nostalgia lane.  So far, it has been an enjoyable way to spend a few hours a day, and as far as fighting games go, there are many aspects to be enjoyed in here.

At first glance the combat system may be somewhat shallow and simple in theory. The tutorial is quite effective to review the basics, and highly recommended unless you are familiar with similar games. But after some experience and the pursuit to tackle challenges and achievements, you get to appreciate a depth that some fighting games lack, as the combos, supermoves, charged attacks, escapes and throws all coalescence into a much richer and fluid combat experience that more limited games, such as 2d fighting games.  The combat can be quite hectic, and amusingly, I found it much more fast paced, full of action and entertaining than what the nostalgia tinted memories of the show seem to recall.

A controller is highly recommended and preffered, though using keyboard is viable.

Pros:
-Fairly welcoming combat system that will take a little bit of practice, but reveals versatility, fun and plenty of action.
- Plenty of characters, it is quite likely that you will find your favourite character or learn to love some other characters you never quite thought you'd find useful.
- Music, sound, multilanguage support both in audio an subtitles. From what I've learned, this is the first time the series includes Latin Spanish. This was a huge plus in my case. But you can configure audio and subtitles in many languages too, as well as the original japanese.
- Art style is very faithful to the source, the visuals are also top notch with plenty of reflections, special effects and animations.
-Story, online play, VS mode, and tons and tons of challenges and unlockables to work for. The game has plenty of things to do.
-Tested the game in 2 pcs, one high end, oone mid end, and performed quite alright and stable in both, even if running at lower settings. High settings are visually pleasing.
- Pretty faithful to the spirit of the source anime. All our favourite clichés are here: Everybody keeps dying in story mode and getting back on their feet by the next episode; Saori is terrible at making decisions and always plays the kidnapped damsel in distress; Ikki keeps watching over Shun, dying, and then returning to protect his bro even though Shun is terribly powerful on his own right; Hyoga is mama´s boy and keeps losing friends, family and rivals; Shiryu keeps losing and gaining his eyesight and has plenty of wise teachings from his old master; Seiya keeps getting his ♥♥♥ beaten by the final boss and all of his friends keep giving him the last bits of their cosmos so he can overcome... except Ikki, because he's both a hardass and too badass to care.

Cons:
- Lots and lots of grinding needed to obtain IG coins to purchase characters, armors, items, support phrases, scenes, music, etc.  You need to do the story mode and some challenges and then some more in order to unlock your favourite characters.
- Difficulty level can be too much, but it is adjustable, so that's nice.
- Some questionable breaks in the tempo of spoken phrases in languages other than japanese, mostly because of syncing" with character talking animations.
-Shadows seemed too blocky at times. Might be a driver thing
date: have to explore more on that
recommended:
but didn{t particularly impact performance. Just... looked off when compared to how shiny and detailed character and background visuals are.


I highly recommend the game to anyone looking into it. It is a fun
